pros: Those who leave always end up coming back; it’s a good company.
cons: Non-profits often don’t pay enough but you’re doing good work

pros: The actual work is rewarding, helping youth overcome their struggles.
cons: Very high stress with little support. Micromanaged to the point of suffocation but no real training or support to help you know how to properly do your job. You're there for a year and still don't feel you know what you're doing. Everyone is spread out so there isn't a coworker to help you when needed. The only training was watching videos and reading a binder when you are brand new and have no idea what you're doing to ask good questions. They want you to flex your schedule to work around appointments but really you end up putting in 10 hour days without compensation.

review_title: Expect to be thrown in the deep end
pros: Great co-workers that collaborate well.
cons: I got very little training. I was expected to shadow colleagues, but that was not adequate for me. They were clearly very busy and couldn't take time to explain everything I needed to know. I need structure and thorough training, especially since the county has such stringent requirements with documentation. Leadership likes to make you think they care about your mental wellness, but they clearly don't by setting you up to fail and not being able to carry a heavy caseload that should be covered by hiring more staff.

review_title: Stay away if you don’t like burnout and zero training
job_title: Licensed Psychiatric Technician in Sacramento, CA
pros: Helping those who are in crisis
cons: Little pay, too much workload, not enough staff coverage.

job_title: Program Support Assistant in Vacaville, CA
pros: Turning Point is an asset to differently-abled populations and offers an array of services for clients and employees. I thoroughly enjoyed the 13-week training we were given about basic behavioral and mental health-related topics. I felt more prepared stepping into this role as a program support assistant.
cons: I would like to see the administrative side included in more client briefings as we are the first line of communication. I think better staff communication and inclusion would benefit the company.

review_title: Great Place to Get Your Foot in the Door Working in Mental Health
job_title: Rehabilitative Coverage Counselor  in Sacramento, CA
pros: - Great benefits for those working over 32+ hours. - Rewards you for going to school. - Allows to move up and grow within the company the longer you stay.
cons: - On the lower fair salary range for most positions. - First degree level to see a benefit is completing a BA. - Could give more support to students / make it more student friendly. - Needs to work on a solution regarding assisting those interested in Peer Support work in both getting certified and re-certifying for those that are certified.

pros: A good place to work when you are fresh out of college.
cons: too much work but not enough staff

job_title: Summer Camp Counselor in Modesto, CA
pros: I can’t think of anything
cons: Everything all at once not

pros: They were great to work for, good benefits, easy to talk with, enjoyable atmosphere.
cons: At the time they didn’t have competitive wages.

job_title: Recruiting Coordinator in Rancho Cordova, CA
pros: Great company, people genuinely care about you and want the best for you, and hold true to the values of the company. Quite lenient and understanding about taking time off, including for mental health. This is a company that encourages you to stay there you entire career, if you wish to, and people often do stay for their entire career once they join! I was a contractor and so didn't get their benefits but from what I hear, they're quite good.
cons: Some departments could benefit from better communication (i.e. I'd sometimes learn day-of about recruiting events I was to participate in). Coming from Europe, there are quite a few perks that US companies don't provide that I'm used to, hence the 4 and not 5 stars! (meal-vouchers, gas or bus fare reimbursement to get to and from work, pensions, 5 weeks off per year for vacation, etc).

pros: Flexible, telework options, annual raises
cons: Low pay, expensive benefits, difficult work environments

job_title: Personal Services Coordinator in Sacramento, CA
pros: Team support, training, experience/knowledge gained
cons: It can be challenging work in general and despite training it's easier said than done not to take the work home with you (emotionally).

review_title: A place of integrity and compassion
job_title: Clinical Team Leader in Sacramento, CA
pros: A truly amazing and special place to work. I am so proud to have worked there for 15 years. I grew and developed as a person and a professional thanks to the extremely intelligent, compassionate, and supportive leadership. The only reason I transitioned was due to family needs. Turning Point will always have a place in my heart and I would not be surprised if I return in some capacity some day.
cons: A very select few have unfairly given Turning Point a bad name, likely due to their own lack of integrity and poor work ethic.

pros: You can wear everyday comfortable clothes
cons: Its honestly not worth the pay

job_title: Behavioral Health Specialist (BHS) in Grass Valley, CA
pros: Great environment, good benefits and pay
cons: I really have no cons

pros: Supportive and caring supervision and staff
cons: Often over worked and underpaid employees

pros: I really enjoyed workign with the people there, Pay was fair.
cons: the training was unstructured inconsistent and chaotic for me. Good for people who are comfortable with being thrown into their job without training.

pros: loved the students great people to work with overall and super work life friendly
cons: mentally taxing something you need to be prepared for

job_title: Senior HR Representative in Rancho Cordova, CA
pros: The HR staff is not supported by senior leadership the way the program staff is. HR has toxic leadership and they do nothing about it which causes excessive turnover. As an HR representative you are constantly talked down to, made to feel like you’re stupid, and even talked about by HR leadership.
cons: Too many to list here

pros: Working with a diverse team
cons: Staff put a lot of pressure on productivity

pros: Fulfilling and meaningful work, invested and engaged leadership, well established agency, ongoing training opportunities, fair wages, multiple program designed leading to a well rounded experience base, well respected agency.
cons: Wages are fair and have been recently restructured, but could be higher.

pros:
Amazing office work environment
Helpful supervisors

Low pay
Stressful environment

pros: The clients are the ones who make the job to look forward to.
cons: The pay is low, management best interest is money over employees, unfair work schedules.

job_title: Program Support Assistant in Chico, CA
pros: Benefits, awesome staff, and excellent leadership. Opportunities for promotions within the company as well. Really cool company that does everything they can to help clients while maintaining healthy work - home boundaries/balance. They really make sure you are taking care of yourself as well at work.
cons: I don't really have any cons to share at this point in time. I'm very happy with my position and how I am treated at work.

job_title: Certified Alcohol and Drug Counselor in Yolo, CA
pros: Autonomy, wide array of clients seeking recovery from dual diagnosis services. Able to provide daily recovery groups with little micro-managing. Great colleagues!
cons: Never eugh time to get treatment plans and ASAMs done in time due to high case load and case management which exceeds what DMC will reimburese for per month.

pros:
Great coworkers

A lot of autonomy in day to day duties-no micromanaging
meaningful work

challenging workload
burn out
very emotionally demanding
not very competitive pay-raises are rare
Benefits have declined-more expensive per check and out of pocket and less coverage

review_title: It’s okay for a brand new clinician.
pros: A place to receive clinical hours quickly
cons:
High turnover
Lots of work for low pay

pros: Flexibility, PTO, Medical Benefits, Warm environment,
cons: Upper management is out of touch but often create space for staff to be heard. Low pay (non-profit). HR is disorganized.

job_title: Senior Vice President in Houston, TX
pros: Good leadership and support for teams
cons: Poor leadership values and actions

job_title: Mental Health Worker I in Sacramento, CA
pros: Working with people who are passionate in helping others, learning more about mental health, good management, you can count on your team
cons: high employer turnover rate, challenging, do so much for such little pay

pros: Working with the members. Some flexibility in your schedule
cons:
Toxic environment that rewards mediocrity.
The reward for going above and beyond at this agency is more work. You need to have strong boundaries in place to make it at Turning Point, they will take all you are willing to give.

review_title: Great place to work if you can keep up with paperwork
pros: Management supportive of employees personally and professionally.
cons: Lots of paperwork on a daily basis.

job_title: Turning Point Community Programs in Moultrie, GA
pros: Schedule was flexible pay was good

job_title: Behavioral Health Associate I in Sacramento, CA

family like setting

job_title: Mental Health Worker in Sacramento, CA
pros: this place has no pros to list
cons: this place is a hot mess. They don't value their employees and they overwork you and blame you being burnt out on yourself. upper management is no help when it comes to problems going on within the program. the pay sucks for all the work they want you to do and they have issues with employees trying to build morale within the program.

pros: You will have the most amazing clients and you'll truly make a positive difference!
cons: Management has SO MUCH drama. They also target employees who speak up for themselves and their clients.

pros: Great work environment and work/life balance

pros: They hire with little experience.
cons: Low funding when it comes to pay

job_title: Client Support Coordinator in Fairfield, CA
pros: Wonderful staff, enjoyable job, decent pay, great benefits, great management. Honestly, I love my job! I love working with my clients. Management is very understanding if you need a mental health day or a day off. I am able to take time of when I need it, or want it. I can't express to you all how much I love my job!
cons: Honestly, I can't think of any other than I wish we were offered a pay increase for our performance.

pros: A lot of support and freedom to do the job hired to do. Very hands off approach and no micro management. Directors and Supervisors are fast to respond and very helpful.
cons: I can't think of any cons for this organization. There was not a lot of direction given for the position, which made it challenging, but I personally enjoyed that aspect very much.

job_title: Lead Resident Client Supervisor in Bakersfield, CA
pros: None. Zero. Zilch. Run. Hide
cons: Too many to list. Crappy work environment

pros: Good people to work with, Company sort of cares, the clients are great. You can move within the company fairly easy.
cons: Low pay if you have a B.A/B.S, Drive your own vehicle, and they don't pay for damage if on company time doing company business.

job_title: Personal Services Coordinator III in Sacramento, CA
pros: Good place for work experience for new college graduates.
cons: A lot of work and under paid.

pros: This company invests in their employees, providing excellent training opportunities.
cons: You hear about some centers having bad management but I never personally experienced this.

pros: Benefits, Hours, Supervision, Weekdays, Coworkers
cons: Pay, Lack of support, High Caseload

review_title: Let the employees assist with dictating policy
pros: supportive management within program, room for creativity and bringing new ideas to the table, flexible work day and self-scheduling for the most part. People who work in the field tend to be excellent friends and listeners. My network has grown tremendously. You can get supervision hours for your educational or license requirements.
cons:
Upper and corporate management is out of touch with what their programs actually DO day to day, leading them to enact arbitrary policies in the name of "self-care". It is obvious to every employee that these policy changes are made in an effort to micromanage employees and protect the corporate interests of upper management. 
High HR turnover has created a steep decline in the quality of recruitment efforts.
Upper management refuses to take action on lazy or incompetent employees, while letting hard workers experience significant burnout to carry their burden.
Favoritism is ALIVE and well.
No room for growth or promotions.
No raises for nearly a decade.

pros: You will gain experience and clients are great
cons: Direct service employees are very underpaid. Do not expect to get a raise. They will tell you they do not have a budget. However the new CEO still makes over six figures a year. They talk about social justice but they are unjust to their employees. If Your degree cost you a lot of money and time then do now waste your time here. They expect you to have at least a four year degree with a $11 hourly pay. No one can survive on that and pay loans. HR has always ignored complaints about co worker arriving late to work. Obviously some favoritism. also expect to work a lot of OT if not Management will make you feel like you are not a team player.

job_title: Person Service Coordinator III in Sacramento, CA
pros: Working with the members and co-workers, support from co-workers in very tense and trying situations due to member's mental illness; loved working with the members !
cons: Weak Mgmt who want to make sure you know they are Mgmt and you ARE NOT. Billing is a constant issue and takes away from the work; CEO has favorites and only concerned with billing and making money; horrible pay and no appreciation from Upper or middle Mgmt .  Needs to be revamped from the top (CEO) down.

pros: Free high program on workshop client at work. Dependent and modest works like clock in and out job workday fashion. My goals are to clean around various areas at the workplace
cons: Nothing makes me important to make check points on getting my job done but everything counts to my cleaning with an time limit. Sometimes I get loose on tracking down my appointments with my co-op.

review_title: Fun! Great population this position is geared to advocate for...love what TP does for mental health field.
pros: Excellent time off policies when u need it!
cons: Minimal leadership skills and lack of ongoing training on how Team Leader approach their PSC's. Micromanaging at times where they feel certain issues may result in their blame. Inconsistency of policy enforced from PSC to PSC.

pros: Flexibility with schedules and good co-worker relationships
cons: Low pay for the amount of work asked to do, minimal support from upper management, documentation heavy

pros: Most rewarding job EVER!  The only job that  where I liked every single single person I worked with!
cons: Long hours, and if you worked off-shifts, the staff meetings had you falling asleep.

job_title: Personal Services Coordinator III in Sacramento, CA
pros: Great and Competent Staff. People are understanding and care about one another in this company. I love the services that Turning Point Provides Clients. I highly respect the CEO and management staff! Great accrual for time off and  I was highly supported during my personal struggles.
cons: I have no cons to report. I genuinely love my job with Turning Point!

job_title: Director of Housing in Sacramento, CA
pros: Working at TPCP allows you to work with colleagues and leadership who are competent and have great levels of integrity.  There are many opportunities for career advancement and growth.
cons: Benefits tend to be expensive; however, leadership is always working to address this issue and explore creative options for employees.

pros: Amazing staff who truly care and try to connect as a team so that they serve families better.
cons: Social service agencies, in general, don't pay very well-- but it's just the funding issues-- no fault on Turning Point.
